site_title: Leftovers reboot
summary: A Singaporean food blog shares creative ways to repurpose leftover food from the Chinese New Year reunion dinner. The blog offers five recipes: Chai Mui, Deep-Fried Fish Cake, Potato Pie, Stuffed Mushroom Canape, and Braised Duck with Arrowhead. These dishes are designed to be easy to make and use leftover ingredients, helping to reduce food waste and make the most of festive feasts. The blog aims to inspire readers to think creatively about their leftovers and enjoy a guilt-free Chinese New Year celebration.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Singapore's social spending may not be a fiscal burden, analysts say. The emerging market currency rout is expected to dent MNCs' profits. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong plans to present a "little hongbao" to pioneer seniors. GIC invested in an Australian student accommodation company, while CDL Hospitality Trusts reported a stable Q4 distribution. Consumer confidence in Singapore remains stable, despite concerns about job prospects. The Singapore Exchange's China A50 Futures hit a record volume of 21.9 million contracts last year.

site_title: Sing dollar to remain weak this year: Julius Baer
summary: Singapore's currency, the Singapore dollar (SGD), is expected to remain weak this year due to a decline in foreign investment. According to Mark Matthews, Bank Julius Baer's head of research Asia, the SGD's value has decreased by 6% against the US dollar since 2011 and is now around $1.27. This weakening currency makes Singaporean assets less attractive to international investors. Additionally, Matthews predicts a 10% correction in residential property prices over the next 12 months due to a surge in new supply and a decrease in demand.

site_title: RoboCop's back with a vengeance
summary: The 2014 film RoboCop, directed by Jose Padilha, reimagines the classic 1987 sci-fi character. The movie follows a slain police officer resurrected as a high-tech cyborg, exploring themes of identity, socio-political commentary, and satire. With a mix of action, violence, and humor, the film stands out from the genre. Despite its troubled production history, RoboCop 2014 has received praise for its well-rounded storytelling, making it an exception to the typical action flick.

site_title: Gift companies report brisk orders for CNY hampers
summary: Singapore's gift companies report brisk orders for Chinese New Year hampers, with Noel Gifts International and Humming Flowers & Gifts expecting a 3-5% and 5-10% increase in sales respectively. Despite higher costs, companies are maintaining prices, with eight out of nine businesses surveyed saying they have kept prices steady. Online sales have also increased, with e-commerce companies placing orders through Xpressflower.com and Angel Florist's website. Consumers are opting for premium hampers in boxes or baskets, and businesses are expecting last-minute orders to bolster sales.

site_title: Pioneer S'poreans to receive 'a little hongbao': PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced plans to present a "little hongbao" to the pioneer generation, who have played a significant role in building the country, ahead of its 50th birthday. The government is working on a Pioneer Generation Package to honor this group, which is expected to cover their medical needs. Details of the package will be revealed in the upcoming Budget Speech.

site_title: Home prices in 20 US cities up in Nov
summary: Home prices in 20 US cities rose 13.7% from November 2012, the largest 12-month gain since February 2006, according to the S&P/Case-Shiller index. A limited housing supply and growing income and job growth are contributing to the appreciation. Despite higher mortgage rates, economists predict further strides in the housing market this year. Home prices adjusted for seasonal variations rose 0.9% in November, with Atlanta and Miami leading the month-over-month gains.

site_title: China's January PMI slips to six-month low of 49.5
summary: China's manufacturing contracted for the first time in six months in January, with HSBC's PMI falling to 49.5, a six-month low. This marks the first time Chinese manufacturing has contracted since July 2018. The drop raises concerns over China's growth prospects for the year.

site_title: Animal spirits
summary: A satirical article from 2014 predicts the fortunes of various animals based on their zodiac signs. The Year of the Horse is said to bring contention and chaos, while the Ox is advised to watch out for signs on the Marina Coastal Expressway. Other animals, such as the Tiger, Rabbit, and Snake, face various challenges and misfortunes. The article concludes that the Horse's lucky number is 4, but also notes that certain combinations of numbers and colors bring bad luck. The piece is a humorous take on astrology and the zodiac.

site_title: Total market cap slips again, hits 13-month low
summary: Singapore-listed stocks experienced a fourth consecutive month of decline, with the total market capitalisation hitting a 13-month low of $873 billion in January. This represents a 2.9% decrease from December. Despite this, analysts remain optimistic for the rest of 2014, citing emerging Asia's potential for growth.

images.alt_text: Companies that will benefit from the US Federal Reserve's tapering, such as banks, could also offer value buys - PHOTO: REUTERS

site_title: SGX A50 futures hit record 21.9m contracts last year
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a record annual volume of 21.9 million contracts for its China A50 Futures, a 119% growth from 2012. This represents a significant increase in trading activity, with over US$2 billion in open positions as of December 2013.

site_title: Fed to stick with stimulus reduction despite sell-off
summary: The Federal Reserve announced it will continue to reduce its economic support, cutting the stimulus from $75 billion in January to $65 billion in February, despite recent global market turmoil. This decision aims to scale back its support for the US economy.

site_title: Manufacturing firms upbeat on H1 outlook
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector expects improved business conditions over the next six months, with a net weighted balance of 4% foreseeing a more favorable situation. In contrast, the services sector is less optimistic, with a net weighted balance of 1% expecting tougher conditions. The manufacturing sector projects higher output in the first quarter, while services firms expect higher earnings and some firms plan to increase hiring. The economy expanded 4.4% in Q4 2013, driven by the manufacturing sector's 3.5% growth.

site_title: Open call for the next arts star
summary: Singapore's Singapore International Festival of Arts is launching an open call for its O.P.E.N. initiative, inviting 100 individuals to join free workshops in sound art, contemporary dance, theatrical works, or multimedia installations. Participants will be selected to showcase their work in mid-July, with the goal of fostering creativity and self-expression. The workshops, led by well-known artists, aim to help participants tap into their inner child and explore their artistic side, regardless of their background or profession.

site_title: AIMS AMP Reit's Q3 DPU up 7.4% at 2.77 cents
summary: AIMS AMP Capital Industrial Reit's Q3 DPU rose 7.4% to 2.77 cents, driven by a 26.3% increase in distribution to unitholders and 26.6% growth in net property income. The trust secured 12 new leases, pushing occupancy to 98.2%, and is focusing on development and acquisition opportunities in Singapore, including the 20 Gul Way redevelopment and Defu Lane pipeline.

site_title: Qantas, Virgin get nod for controversial debit cards
summary: Qantas and Virgin Australia Holdings have been given a "no-action" letter by the Australian Securities and Investment Commission (ASIC) regarding their plans to send unsolicited debit cards to millions of frequent flyer members, potentially violating consumer law. The airlines' plans, which were met with criticism, have not faced any regulatory response.

site_title: Flights cancelled as ATCs across Europe strike
summary: Air traffic controllers across Europe have begun a two-day strike to protest against planned cost cuts and reforms. Flights were cancelled at 440 airports, with Deutsche Lufthansa cancelling 42 and Ryanair Holdings scrapping over 80 flights. The strike affects nine million flights per year, causing disruptions and potential delays. The ATCs claim safety is not considered a priority in the performance scheme and are refusing cuts in staff. The strike is expected to continue through yesterday, with airlines advising customers to check flight status before traveling.

site_title: Help elderly, poor join MediShield Life: panel
summary: Singapore's MediShield Life review committee calls for government support to encourage elderly and low-income individuals to join the enhanced national medical insurance plan. The committee, which includes feedback from focus group discussions and consultations, suggests that the government help those who are currently uninsured and provide support for the elderly. The committee also recommends covering premiums with Medisave and exploring integrated shield plans with greater regulation and standardization. MediShield Life is expected to be launched in 2015, with better coverage and lifelong protection for all Singaporeans, including those with pre-existing medical conditions.

site_title: Nintendo plans US$1.2b share buyback
summary: Nintendo plans a $1.2 billion share buyback in response to poor sales of its Wii U console, largely due to competition from smartphones, tablets, and consoles like the PS4 and Xbox One. The company will buy back up to 10 million shares, approximately 7.8% of outstanding shares. Nintendo has $8.6 billion in cash and no debt, and the move aims to boost the company's value and appeal to investors.

site_title: Lufthansa to fly A380s to India this year
summary: Lufthansa plans to begin flying Airbus A380 superjumbo jets to India later this year, following India's lifting of a ban on landing the aircraft. The German airline had no immediate plans to use the jet on those routes but is now interested in utilizing the A380 for major Indian markets, according to Christoph Franz, CEO of Deutsche Lufthansa AG.

site_title: American Airlines' profit beats expectations
summary: American Airlines reported better-than-expected adjusted profit and revenue in its fourth quarter, with shares rising 4% due to fare increases and lower fuel costs. The carrier's demand trends were strong, and it expects revenue growth of 2-4% in the first quarter. Despite a net loss of $2 billion, excluding merger costs, combined profit was $436 million, beating analyst expectations. The merger of American and US Airways has been seen as a potential driver of stronger financial performance.

images.alt_text: Merger benefits: American plans to improve Q4 results by combining operations with US Airways after the recent merger. A new reservations system will allow customers to book flights on both airlines. - PHOTO: BLOOMBERG

site_title: SGD bonds holding up as choppy market raises risk
summary: Singaporean investors are flocking to bonds as market volatility increases, with the Markit iBoxx SGD Corporates Index up 0.5% year-to-date despite a 4.4% decline in the Straits Times Index. DBS's head of fixed income, Clifford Lee, attributes this trend to investors seeking capital preservation amid fears of tapering and market uncertainty. Recent bond issues, including a S$200 million six-year deal at 3.35%, have seen long-term investors take the majority of the transactions, with funds, insurance, and banks also participating.

site_title: Yeehaw: festive round-up of corporate horses
summary: A Year of the Horse has begun, bringing with it a surge in fortunes for some Chinese tech entrepreneurs, including Pony Ma, China's richest man, and Jack Ma, Alibaba's executive chairman. The horse is considered the strongest Fire animal in the 12 zodiac signs, and its connection is reflected in various brands, such as Ferrari's prancing horse emblem and the Ford Mustang. Luxury brands like Coach and Hermes have also used horse imagery in their logos and designs, with Polo Ralph Lauren Corporation taking a particularly aggressive stance in protecting its "Polo" brand.

site_title: Mixed bag of treats
summary: New Chinese film "From Vegas to Macau" stars Chow Yun Fat as a casino security expert with a unique ability to read cards by touch. The action-comedy film, directed by Wong Jing, also features Nicholas Tse and Chapman To. Despite its absurdity, Chow's charisma saves the film, making it a decent but not outstanding option for the Lunar New Year box-office. The film marks a return to Wong Jing's signature genre, blending slapstick humor with action.

site_title: Boeing Q4 profit up, but tougher 2014 awaits
summary: US aerospace giant Boeing reported a 26.1% rise in profits in its fourth quarter, driven by record commercial aircraft deliveries, reaching US$1.2 billion in net earnings. Revenues increased to US$23.8 billion, up from US$22.3 billion in the previous year. However, the company signaled a leaner 2014 profit outlook due to last year's boom.

site_title: Singapore bank lending growth slows in December
summary: Singapore bank lending growth slowed in December, with domestic banking unit loans increasing 1.5% from November, the weakest month-on-month growth since February 2009. Consumer loans rose 0.3% and business loans grew 2.3% in December, with a 17% yearly increase in DBU loans. Factors contributing to the slowdown include the US Fed's tapering of QE and a softening property market, with regulators scrutinizing the segments for excessive debt.

site_title: Singapore luxury watch market remains tough
summary: The Singapore luxury watch market continued to face challenges in 2013, with local retailers experiencing poor sales despite efforts to drum up business through deep discounts. However, quarterly balance sheets from major retailers The Hour Glass and F J Benjamin showed a slight increase in sales between July and September. The Federation of the Swiss Watch Industry reported that Swiss watch exports to Singapore inched up 0.9% last year, reaching 1.04 billion Swiss francs. Despite this, the overall Swiss watch exports remained flat, with only a 1.7% year-on-year increase to nearly 20 billion Swiss francs.

site_title: BlackRock helps revive Japan's property market
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest money manager, is helping to revive Japan's property market as investors expect Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's economic growth plan to boost real estate returns. In 2013, Japan real estate investment trusts (J-Reits) acquired 2.23 trillion yen worth of properties, almost triple the previous year. This follows a record amount of cash raised from equity sales and easing of monetary policy. Real estate investment has increased since Abe's pledge to end deflation, leading to growth in commercial land values and a drop in office vacancy rates.

site_title: Transpacific container lines to up freight rates
summary: Container shipping lines, including Maersk Line, MSC, and others, will raise Asia-US freight rates in two stages, starting March 15 with a $300 increase per 40-foot container, and then by an unknown amount from May 1. The move aims to halt losses, following a January general rate increase that added $300 per container. The Transpacific Stabilization Agreement, comprising 15 major shipping lines, will implement the rate increases to stabilize the industry.

site_title: Quarterly reporting essential in disclosure-based regime
summary: Quarterly reporting is a topic of debate among companies, regulators, auditors, and investors. While some argue that more frequent reporting helps the market and aids investment decision-making, others claim the costs outweigh the benefits due to short-termism and share price volatility. Countries like the US and Canada have adopted quarterly reporting, despite objections, as it is seen as essential for a disclosure-based regime that requires continuous updates on financial performance and outlook. The usefulness of quarterly reporting depends on the market's efficiency and the quality of analysis available.

site_title: Gallerist stuns with new art space
summary: Gallerist Pearl Lam has opened her new art space in Gillman Barracks, Singapore, showcasing works by five abstract artists from around the world, including Christine Ay Tjoe, Su Xiaobai, and Zhi Jinshi. The exhibition features a diverse range of styles, from Su's minimalist intensity to Zhu Jinshi's textured, three-dimensional canvases. The gallery's large size allows each work to be displayed individually, preventing overcrowding and showcasing the artists' unique talents. Lam's first show in Singapore has received praise for its exquisite taste and diverse selection.

site_title: More social spending not 'a fiscal drain on economy'
summary: Singapore's government is expected to increase social spending, with analysts arguing it will create jobs and fresh growth areas, rather than being a fiscal drain. The increased investment in healthcare, education, and social services is seen as a response to medium-term socioeconomic trends, such as an ageing population and income inequality. Experts believe that sustainable social spending can promote growth, efficiency, and alleviate negative externalities, and that it is a signal that policymakers are taking proactive steps to address these challenges.

site_title: GIC buys stake in Australian student-hostel group
summary: GIC has invested in Australian student-accommodation company Iglu through a joint venture with Macquarie Capital, acquiring a majority stake in the company. Iglu's A$150m property portfolio comprises over 900 beds across three properties in Sydney and Brisbane. The deal is the largest in the Australian student-accommodation sector and is seen as a significant investment opportunity, with yields ranging from 7-7.5%. GIC's investment follows a trend of institutional investors increasing exposure to alternative asset classes, including the Australian student-accommodation market.

site_title: Indicators point to impending rise in soured loans
summary: Moody's Investors Service warns of an impending rise in soured loans in Singapore, citing declining retail spending and industrial production indices. The credit-rating agency expects a correlation between household cash flow pressure and an increase in consumer problem loans. Industrial production, however, showed surprising strength in December, leading to revised GDP growth forecasts. Moody's also notes that the property sector, despite existing caution, is expected to maintain stable asset quality due to recent Monetary Authority of Singapore measures.

site_title: Investment commitments robust: EDB
summary: Singapore attracted $12.1 billion in fixed-asset investments last year, a drop from $16 billion in 2012, but within EDB's forecast range. Despite rising costs and a tighter labor market, the agency predicted steady investment levels for this year. The investments are expected to create 21,400 skilled jobs and $7.8 billion in total business expenditure, with electronics and chemical sectors seeing significant declines. EDB chairman Leo Yip attributed the 2012 spike to one-off projects, and the agency remains attractive to foreign investors.

site_title: CRCT's Q4 DPU dips 4.3% to 2.20 cents
summary: CRCT's distribution per unit (DPU) for Q4 2013 decreased 4.3% to 2.20 cents, despite a 5.6% increase in income available for distribution to $17.7 million. The decline was due to an enlarged base of issued units. Unitholders will receive their Q4 DPU on March 27, totaling 4.33 cents for the quarter.

site_title: Japan searches for new jets to carry emperor, PM
summary: Japan plans to replace its ageing Boeing 747-400s used for official visits by the emperor and prime minister with new jets starting in April 2019. The government aims to introduce planes with secure communication devices and equipment, and Boeing and Airbus are interested in pitching for the order. The new planes will need to be able to fly directly to the US east coast, where Washington is approximately 10,900 kilometers from Tokyo.

site_title: Iran oil-shipping insurance ambiguous
summary: US and EU sanctions on Iran are set to expire or be renewed on July 20, leaving insurance ambiguity for tankers carrying Iranian oil. Ship owners may not receive payouts if they claim against insurance policies after July 20, despite eased sanctions. This uncertainty may restrict growth in Iranian oil exports, which fell 60% since 2012, and could impact vessel owners' willingness to carry Iranian oil.

site_title: Marathon zooms in on distressed debt in Europe
summary: Marathon Asset Management has launched a $530 million distressed debt fund in Europe, focusing on Spain, Germany, and Ireland. The fund aims to profit from improving economic prospects in the region, where European banks are offloading unwanted assets amid new regulations. This move follows other hedge funds and private equity firms that have invested in the region, and Marathon plans to buy non-performing loans, distressed real estate loans, and mortgage-backed securities. The fund's strategy aligns with bank deleveraging and asset sales, driven by the recovery of European sovereign credits and financial institutions.

site_title: Lower Manhattan landlords compete for bank's tenancy
summary: Bank of New York Mellon is selling its 50-storey headquarters at 1 Wall Street and plans to move to smaller space in lower Manhattan or New Jersey, sparking a fierce competition among developers. The search highlights the challenges in the commercial district, where vacant office space is abundant despite new construction. The battle for the bank's tenancy also illustrates the use of public subsidies to fill office towers under construction at the World Trade Center site.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Singapore maintained strong foreign investment commitments despite rising costs and a tighter labor market in 2013, according to the Economic Development Board (EDB). Changi Airport broke passenger records, while the MediShield Life review committee called for support for the elderly to afford the plan. SMRT's Q3 profit fell 44% and Eu Yan Sang's Q2 net profit declined 31%. The Braddell View HUDC estate was designated for privatization, and CIMB shares fell due to earnings dilution fears.

site_title: Singapore does well in protection of IP rights
summary: Singapore ranks fourth globally in protecting and enforcing intellectual property rights, scoring 25.1 points out of 30, according to a GIPC study. The country excelled in its national IP framework and enforcement of trademarks and copyrights, but struggled with peer-to-peer file sharing and trademark counterfeiting. Despite weaknesses, the GIPC praises Singapore's robust and efficient civil remedies, judicial environment, and legal framework.

site_title: More social spending not 'a fiscal drain on economy'
summary: Singapore's government plans to increase social spending, which analysts argue can create jobs and fresh growth areas, rather than being a fiscal drain. This investment is aimed at addressing concerns such as an ageing population, healthcare affordability, and income inequality. The upcoming Pioneer Generation Package is expected to provide sustainable support to elderly Singaporeans who contributed to the country's development. Experts emphasize the need for a comprehensive support system for seniors, including transport concessions and incentives for companies to retain older workers.

site_title: Japan's Boeing 787 probe looking at overheated battery
summary: Japanese investigators are examining a recent lithium-ion battery meltdown on a parked Japan Airlines 787 Dreamliner to determine the cause of a similar incident on an ANA Holdings 787 last year. The earlier incident destroyed evidence, while the latest incident on a redesigned battery with insulation resulted in only one cell being damaged. The investigation, led by the Japan Transport Safety Board, aims to find the root cause of the overheating and may lead to further design changes to prevent similar incidents. The incident has prompted authorities to ground the global fleet of Dreamliners for over three months.

site_title: Changi Airport sets new passenger milestones
summary: Changi Airport set a record for the year, handling 53.7 million passengers in 2013, a 5% increase from 2012. The airport also broke monthly and daily records, with 5.12 million passengers in December and 191,800 passengers in a 24-hour period on Christmas Eve. Changi's passenger traffic bumped it up to fifth position among the world's busiest airports. The airport expects a 3-5% growth rate in passenger throughput in 2014, with an increase in airfreight movements to 1.85 million tonnes. New airlines, including Ethiopian and Uzbekistan, joined the airport's network last year and will this year.

site_title: Eu Yan Sang Q2 net falls 31% on interest expense, taxes
summary: Eu Yan Sang, a traditional Chinese medicine retailer, reported a 31% decline in its net profit to $3.2 million for its second quarter ended Dec 31, 2013, due to higher interest costs and taxes. Despite this, the company's core retail business grew 18% across most markets, while revenue reached $91.9 million. Earnings per share fell to 0.72 cents from 1.05 cents a year earlier.

site_title: EM currency rout may hit profits of Europe, US and Japan MNCs
summary: The emerging market currency rout is expected to negatively impact European, US, and Japanese multinational companies, as exports to nations with major currency devaluations could suffer significant falls. Companies with direct emerging market exposure have underperformed markets, while hedging against currency declines is costly due to higher interest rates in emerging countries. Exports to affected nations, such as India and Brazil, are expected to decline, leading to lower demand for foreign goods and potentially weaker emerging-market economies in the short term.

site_title: Maybank Singapore appoints new CEO
summary: Maybank Singapore appoints Lim Hong Tat as its new CEO, effective immediately, replacing Pollie Sim. Lim, 54, brings over 30 years of banking experience, previously heading community financial services in Malaysia and serving as CEO of Maybank's Philippines office. He will oversee Maybank's operations in Singapore and develop new market segments. Maybank Group president Abdul Farid Alias praised Lim's experience in the consumer banking segment, expecting him to accelerate growth in consumer and business banking segments.

site_title: M'sian consumer confidence at lowest ebb since 2009: poll
summary: Malaysia's consumer confidence has plummeted to its lowest level since the 2009 global financial crisis, according to a survey by the Malaysian Institute of Economic Research. The Consumer Sentiment Index fell to 82.4 points in Q4 '13, driven by rising inflation and increased living costs. Consumers are cutting back on spending, with 40% of households reporting a deterioration in their financial standing, and 92% expecting prices to rise further. This disconnect between macroeconomic numbers and consumer reality is a concern, as the economy is expected to grow 5-5.5% this year.

site_title: IPC quadruples 2013 net profit to $18.2m
summary: IPC Corporation, an IT services provider turned property developer, has reported a 369% increase in its full-year 2013 net profit to $18.2 million. Revenue more than doubled to $46.9 million, driven by sales from its business hotels and condominium projects in Japan. The company has declared dividends and plans to sell remaining stock of completed units in Japan. Its net asset value per share increased to 21.57 cents, and it operates 10 hotels globally, with one set to open in China's Zhuhai in the second quarter of 2014.

site_title: Marriott open to buying hotel operators: CEO
summary: Marriott International CEO Arne Sorenson stated the company is open to buying more hotel-management companies, citing reasons such as adding a new brand, lack of distribution, or economics of a deal. Marriott recently acquired Protea Hospitality Holdings for $186 million, which will nearly double its African rooms to 23,000. The company's growth strategy has shifted, including the introduction of the Moxy budget chain in Europe and a joint venture with AC Hotels. Marriott expects lodging companies to benefit from economic growth this year due to reduced political uncertainty and increased middle-class travel.

site_title: Shakespeare in spiffy cruisewear
summary: A production of Romeo and Juliet by Toy Factory Productions will be staged in a modern, upscale seaside setting, featuring luxury yachts and sailboats instead of Elizabethan-era mansions. The play will be set to music, ranging from R&B to Broadway-style, and the cast will perform in sleek, contemporary cruisewear. Director Nell Ng aims to attract a younger audience to Shakespeare's classic love story, but the challenge remains whether the cast can deliver the Shakespearean language fluently. The production features professional cast members, including Benjamin Kheng and Ethel Yap, who are performing the Bard for the first time.

site_title: Tuan Sing Q4 net falls 68% to $25.3m
summary: Tuan Sing Holdings reported a 68% year-on-year decline in Q4 net profit to $25.3 million, due to slower property sales and fair-value adjustments. Revenue fell 42% to $65.3 million. For the full year, net profit fell by more than half to $52 million. The company remains focused on the property sector and plans to expand its business and acquire more properties in Indonesia.

site_title: Chinese buyers pushing up home prices in Australian cities
summary: Chinese buyers are driving up home prices in Australian cities, particularly in Sydney, where prices have surged as much as 27% in the past year. Many of the neighborhoods experiencing the biggest price gains are popular with Chinese buyers, and foreigners accounted for 12.5% of new home purchases in the three months to September, more than doubling from 5% in 2011. This influx of foreign investment is contributing to housing bubbles in areas like Chatswood and Rhodes, with some suburbs seeing price growth three times faster than the overall market.

site_title: Virus-hit Royal Caribbean cruise ship back at home port
summary: A Royal Caribbean cruise ship, Explorer of the Seas, returned to its home port in Bayonne, New Jersey, after a 10-day Caribbean cruise was cut short due to a stomach bug affecting nearly 700 passengers and crew, with 630 passengers and 54 crew members falling ill. The illnesses were attributed to norovirus, and the cruise line is disinfecting the ship. Passengers are receiving compensation, but some are dissatisfied with the offer, including a full refund. An investigation is underway, with environmental and health experts on board to determine the cause.

images.alt_text: SICK BAY WATCH Altogether, 630 passengers and 54 of the crew of the Explorer of the Seas fell ill. - PHOTO: REUTERS

site_title: Half stake sold in Finexis Bldg at $2,300 psf on strata area
summary: An offshore fund managed by Singapore-based Sin Capital Partners has bought a half-stake in Finexis Building at 108 Robinson Road for $123.8 million, valuing the 12-storey freehold office block at nearly $2,300 per square foot. The deal reflects a net yield of slightly over 2% and follows a similar transaction in 2011, where Sin Capital acquired the other 50% stake for $110 million. The property is currently 96% let, with anchor tenant Finexis Advisory and other tenants including Cliftons and BoxHill Institute.

site_title: More locals employed amid tighter foreign hiring
summary: Singapore's employment numbers show a 4% growth in total employment in 2013, driven by the hiring of locals, with foreign employment contributing 1.6 percentage points to the growth. Higher-wage workers bore the brunt of stricter regulations, while lower-paid foreign workers made up most of the hired foreign labor. Unemployment stayed low at 1.9%, and income growth for Singaporeans strengthened to 7.1% despite inflation easing to 2.4%. The government may need to introduce more pro-productivity schemes to ease labor costs, with the upcoming Budget expected to enhance the Productivity and Innovation Credit (PIC) scheme.

site_title: ICBC extends business to London
summary: ICBC, China's largest bank, agreed to buy a 60% stake in Standard Bank's global markets business in London for $765 million. This deal makes ICBC the first large Chinese lender to have a substantial trading operation in London. The British government has been trying to increase investment from China, and this transaction could be a precursor to investment by other Chinese financial companies. ICBC will gain a five-year option to buy an additional 20% stake in the unit.

site_title: Business briefing
summary: Sino Construction Ltd acquired a 60% stake in Malaysian construction company Elite Bay Sdn Bhd for RM300,000, aiming to leverage Elite Bay's presence in Malaysia for more contract works. Meanwhile, Armada Group reported widening third-quarter losses to HK$13.35 million, despite revenue growth to HK$3.77 million.

site_title: GRP raises $2.78m with placement to Daniel Teo
summary: GRP Ltd has raised $2.78 million through a private placement of 27.8 million new shares to real estate veteran Daniel Teo at 10 cents per share. The funds will be used for new market expansion, business development, and projects. GRP has also signed a letter of intent to acquire a plot of land in Yangon, Myanmar for $12 million. The placement represents 4.98% of the existing share capital and 4.75% of the enlarged share capital. The company's shares will resume trading on Monday after a trading halt.

site_title: No New Year reunion for some China workers
summary: China's migrant workers, who make up 245 million, are choosing not to return home for the New Year due to financial pressures and ridicule from their families. Many earn low wages, with some opting to stay in cities like Beijing to earn bonuses and avoid the costs of gifts and travel. A recent survey found that 36% of migrants cited embarrassment at earning too little as a reason for not returning, with many instead choosing to spend the festival at their workplace.

site_title: Remove highway for Olympics, says Tokyo developer
summary: Mitsui Fudosan Co, Japan's largest developer, is in talks with the government to remove a highway near Tokyo Station ahead of the 2020 Olympic Games. The highway's relocation could boost the area's economy by 3.1 trillion yen through higher property values and increased visitors. The company's president, Masanobu Komoda, cited the highway's negative impact on the environment and scenery as reasons for the proposal. Mitsui Fudosan aims to redevelop the area with office and commercial buildings, and the project could be completed by 2019.

site_title: Drones grounded by US after predator is ditched off California
summary: A US Customs and Border Protection (CBP) drone, a modified General Atomics Aeronautical Systems Inc Predator B, crashed into the Pacific Ocean off California's coast on January 27 due to a mechanical failure. The crew ditched the aircraft to prevent it from causing damage or injury. The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) is investigating the incident, which is the first of its kind for CBP. The incident highlights the need for regulations on the safe integration of unmanned aircraft for commercial use in US airways, which the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) is currently working on.

site_title: Savages rock Laneway festival
summary: The St Jerome's Laneway Music Festival in Singapore featured a lineup of female artists, including Savages, Daughter, Haim, and Chvrches. Vandetta and The Observatory performed, drawing a crowd of over 10,000. James Blake closed the festival with a hauntingly beautiful set, combining dance and soul. The perfect weather added to the success of the event, with all stages receiving blazing performances from the acts. The festival showcased a mix of post-punk, folk, and electronic music, with a focus on female talent.

site_title: Dubai airport overtakes Paris, Frankfurt
summary: Dubai International Airport surpassed Paris Charles de Gaulle and Frankfurt as the world's busiest airport, with 66.4 million passengers in 2014, a 15% increase from the previous year. The airport's growth is attributed to Gulf carriers, particularly Emirates, which is the biggest airline by international traffic. Dubai's expansion plans aim to serve 90 million travelers annually, and its new Al Maktoum base is designed to handle 150 million people. Europe's major airports face pressure from Istanbul Ataturk, which saw a 14% surge in passenger numbers to 51.3 million.

site_title: Exquisite romance with Asian touch
summary: Renowned choreographer Goh Choo San's 1984 interpretation of Romeo and Juliet, created by the Singapore Dance Theatre, is set to be revived. Directed by Janek Schergen, the production is notable for its Asian touch and unique storytelling elements, including the character of Fate, which is embodied by a ballerina in blue. The lead dancers, Rosa Park and Chen Peng, have undergone extensive training to deliver performances matching the beauty and intensity of previous definitive turns, particularly the iconic balcony scene.

site_title: Mixed views on potential MBFC Tower 3 deal
summary: Keppel Reit (K-Reit) is considering divesting its Prudential Tower in Singapore to partially fund the acquisition of Marina Bay Financial Centre (MBFC) Tower 3. Analysts have mixed views on the potential deal, with some rating it as yield accretive and others as neutral to negative. CIMB analyst Pang Ti Wee believes the deal may be challenging due to Prudential Tower's high occupancy rate, while Cushman and Wakefield's Sigrid Zialcita considers the pricing "fairly valued." The acquisition's yield and distribution per unit (DPU) impact will depend on the price point and structure of the deal.

site_title: STATS ChipPAC posts US$6.1m loss in Q4
summary: STATS ChipPAC reported a US$6.1 million loss in Q4, bringing full-year loss to US$41.5 million, as revenues fell 17.8% to US$395 million. The company attributes the decline to a "bifurcation of the smartphone market" with strong growth in low-cost segments. Adjusted Ebitda is expected to be 18-24% of revenue. The company expects a 8-14% decrease in first quarter revenue and US$105-125 million in capital expenditure for new factory construction.

site_title: S Korea to finalise F-35 jet fighter deal this year
summary: South Korea plans to finalize the purchase of 40 F-35 jet fighters from Lockheed Martin later this year, following a third-quarter contract signing after testing and negotiations. The purchase aims to upgrade the country's ageing fleet of Boeing F-4 and F-5 fighters in response to North Korea's growing nuclear threat. The F-35A variant, adopted by the US Air Force, will be chosen, with deliveries expected to begin in 2018. The deal, worth billions of dollars, requires finance ministry and parliamentary approval.

site_title: Body language takes centre stage
summary: T.H.E. Dance Company is set to premiere a full-length piece, "The Ordinary Man," which combines crosstalk, a traditional Chinese comedic performance, with contemporary dance. The dance, developed by eight dancers from Singapore, Taiwan, China, Australia, and the Philippines, features banter and puns in Mandarin and English, as well as other languages and Chinese dialects. The piece addresses everyday issues in Singapore with a humorous twist, showcasing the dancers' hidden talents, according to artistic director Kuik Swee Boon. The production is a unique blend of language, culture, and dance.

site_title: PM: Three goals S'pore should achieve to show it has progressed
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong outlined three key goals for the country's progress: providing good jobs, achieving a higher fertility rate, and having a capable government trusted by its people. These goals are "easy to state but very hard to achieve," and Lee emphasized the need for a balanced approach to achieve them, including investing in education and work-life balance. He also acknowledged the challenges of reaching a fertility rate of 2.1, but stressed the importance of making progress in this area.

site_title: Cruising boom good news for Singapore
summary: Singapore's cruise industry is expected to experience rapid growth, driven by the global demand for cruising, which is predicted to increase by 68% by 2025, reaching 36.4 million passengers. The growing number of cruise ships operating in Asia will require routine maintenance and major refits, benefiting Singapore's ship repair yards. Additionally, the implementation of emission controls, such as scrubber systems, will also create more work for repair yards in the region.

images.alt_text: Star and the other big cruise companies (notably, of course, Carnival) have turned the cruise business into a sector that seems to defy the cyclical nature of the rest of shipping - PHOTO: SPH

site_title: Managing threat from emerging markets
summary: Investors in emerging markets should focus on countries with current account surpluses, as they are less vulnerable to foreign capital flows. The recent concerns about emerging markets reflect the impact of the US Federal Reserve slowing its monetary stimulus and the ongoing unease about Chinese growth. While another Asian/emerging markets crisis is unlikely, the secular cycle has turned against shares in emerging markets relative to those of developed markets. Countries with large current account deficits, such as Brazil, India, and Indonesia, are particularly vulnerable, while those with surpluses, like China and South Korea, are less at risk.

site_title: Durable goods orders in surprise fall
summary: US durable goods orders unexpectedly fell 4.3% in December, the largest decline in five months, indicating a broad-based retreat that raises concerns about business investment cooling in 2014. This drop, coupled with stagnant wages and inconsistent job gains, suggests consumer spending, accounting for 70% of the economy, may not sustain recent gains. Economists forecast a decline in total durable goods orders, prompting some to reduce forecasts, and the decline in demand may prompt a revision to the US economy's growth projections.

site_title: Investments in S'pore chemical sector still strong
summary: Singapore's chemical sector continues to see strong investments, with nearly 2,000 jobs created in the last two years. Despite major companies shutting down operations and laying off hundreds of workers, new investments from Japanese companies are expected to create over 1,500 jobs from 2014 to 2016. The industry's value-add is expected to remain strong, with the government working to manage costs and encourage productivity. EDB chairman Leo Yip expressed confidence in the industry's long-term prospects, saying new projects will absorb retrenchments and create good jobs.

site_title: SBI to start 92b rupee share sale
summary: State Bank of India (SBI) plans to sell up to 58.9 million shares at a discount of 2% to raise over 92 billion rupees (S$1.9 billion). The move aims to bolster its balance sheet, which is weakened by rising bad loans. SBI needs to raise more than 1.2 trillion rupees by March 2018 to meet capital requirements. The bank's capital adequacy ratio has widened to a five-year high of 5.64% due to increasing bad loans. The sale is managed by Citigroup, Deutsche Bank, and other financial institutions.

site_title: Banks woo savers as deposits slide
summary: Banks in Singapore are offering higher interest rates and promotions to attract savers, who have seen deposits decline despite rising interest rates. Key banks such as DBS, UOB, and OCBC are offering top-up rates, cash gifts, and giveaways, including gold-plated figurines. The competition for deposits is expected to intensify, with analysts predicting a shift towards loans as deposits fall. The Monetary Authority of Singapore reports that deposits have fallen 4.4% year-over-year, while loans have grown 17.4% year-over-year.

site_title: DBS is first Shanghai FTZ foreign bank to close deal
summary: DBS Bank (China) has completed the first foreign bank deal in the Shanghai Free Trade Zone (FTZ), providing foreign currency letter of credit financing to Jeans International Trading Co Ltd. This marks a significant milestone for the bank, which began its Shanghai pilot FTZ sub-branch operations on January 7, 2014. The deal highlights the FTZ's potential to rival Hong Kong as a finance hub, with relaxed currency usage and restrictions. DBS plans to expand its trade financing and export letter of credit services in the FTZ.

site_title: Most Reits raise DPU despite US tapering
summary: Most real estate investment trusts (Reits) in Singapore improved their distribution per unit (DPU) in the last reported quarter, despite the US Federal Reserve's tapering of its stimulus program. Reits with locked-in debt at favourable interest rates benefited from the move, with office and retail sector Reits performing well. Notably, Frasers Commercial Trust saw a 29.7% increase in DPU, while others, such as NTT DC Reit, oversaw a successful public offer. The results suggest that Reits are better positioned to weather the impending rise in interest rates.

site_title: Open for CNY
summary: Several restaurants in Singapore are open for Chinese New Year, offering special menus and promotions. Bar-Roque Grill, Brussels Sprouts, Picotin, and Sque are among those open for dining, with unique dishes and festive atmosphere. Restaurant HOME and Paradise Group will be closed on the first day of Chinese New Year, but will resume operations on February 1. Greenhouse and Jiang-Nan Chun offer buffet spreads and special menus, while Jade Restaurant offers set menus and la carte options. Prices vary for each restaurant, ranging from $34 to $178 per adult for buffet spreads.

site_title: Lower iPhone sales renew China fears
summary: Apple's lower-than-expected iPhone sales and weak revenue forecast have renewed fears about Chinese demand and a tepid global market. The company forecast sales of $42 billion to $44 billion for the March quarter, below analyst expectations of $46 billion. Lower iPhone sales and revenue shortfall drew attention, as Apple cedes ground to rivals in China, its No. 2 market. The company's stock fell 8% on the news, wiping out hopes of a growth story in the market. Analysts point to saturated high-end smartphone and tablet markets and the need for new product development to drive growth.

site_title: KrisEnergy buys 60% of exploration block in Thai gulf
summary: KrisEnergy has acquired a 60% stake in exploration block G3/48 in the Gulf of Thailand from Mubadala Petroleum. The deal, worth undisclosed value, includes the transfer of operatorship to KrisEnergy. The block spans 2,917 sq km in shallow waters, covering five separate basins. The acquisition is pending Thai government and block partner approval. This is part of KrisEnergy's expansion into the Gulf of Thailand, following a previous partnership agreement with Mubadala for the Nong Yao oil development in August.

site_title: Court allows Excel Maritime Carriers restructuring plan
summary: US bankruptcy judge Robert Drain approved Excel Maritime Carriers' restructuring plan, cutting debt by over $600 million. Secured lenders, owed $765 million, will receive $300 million in new debt securities and 83% of the reorganized company's equity. The company aims to exit court protection by mid-February.

site_title: Emerging markets no big threat
summary: Emerging markets, which account for nearly 40% of global GDP, experienced their worst start to a year in five, with the MSCI Emerging Markets Index down 7.1% since December 31. Economists say the pain will be limited to a few unbalanced economies, such as Turkey and Argentina, and developed countries like the US and UK can withstand the sell-offs. The risk of contagion is still present, but the US domestic economy is improving, and the Federal Reserve is unlikely to respond to recent market volatility.

site_title: CDLHT Q4 DPS up marginally at 2.92 cents
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts (CDLHT) reported a distribution per stapled security (DPS) of 2.92 cents for the fourth quarter, a 0.7% increase from the previous year, driven by a strong contribution from its Maldives property. Revenue grew 2.8% to $39.4 million, despite a decline in Singapore hotels due to increased supply. The company's gearing remains at 29.7%, and management is comfortable with a gearing rise to around 40%, allowing for potential overseas acquisitions.

images.alt_text: In with the new: The Orchard Hotel Shopping Arcade, now renamed Claymore Link, will be revamped and repositioned as a family-centric mall

site_title: Julius Baer sees EMs taking a further beating
summary: Julius Baer investment specialists predict emerging markets (EMs) will continue to decline, but see opportunities for selective investments in the second half of 2014. They prefer structurally robust economies like South Korea and China, citing growth potential despite concerns about valuations and external adjustments. Analysts also note that China's slowdown could lead to a more efficient private sector and higher growth rates, making Chinese equities attractive. However, South-east Asia is expected to remain sidelined by larger markets and newer stories.

site_title: Nam Cheong clinches deals worth US$70m
summary: Nam Cheong clinches US$70 million deals for five vessels, including four emergency response and rescue vessels and one anchor handling towing supply vessel, with deliveries scheduled for 2015-16. The contracts are expected to positively impact its earnings for fiscal years 2014-2016. The company's CEO attributes the deal to the strong market for rigs and sustained high oil prices, predicting a record-setting year in oil exploration and production spending. The deals boost Nam Cheong's order book to RM1.5 billion, with analysts maintaining "buy" ratings on the stock due to its compelling valuations and buoyant prospects in the OSV sector.

site_title: Jurong Aromatics complex to start up ahead of schedule
summary: Jurong Aromatics Corporation's (JAC) US$2.4 billion refinery/aromatics complex is set to start up in May/June, ahead of schedule. The 100,000-110,000 barrel-per-day condensate splitter will supply the main aromatics complex with raw materials, producing 1.5 million tonnes per annum of aromatics and 2.5 million tonnes per annum of transportation fuels. Despite a still-cloudy market outlook, JAC's production is "underwritten" by its shareholders, who also buy its products, including BP Singapore and SK Energy. The company plans to expand the project, debottlenecking the complex to boost output by 15-20%.

site_title: SMRT's Q3 profit falls 44% to $14.23m
summary: SMRT Corp's Q3 net profit fell 44.1% to $14.23 million due to a $9m operating loss in its fare business. Revenue rose 4.1% to $293.3 million, while operating expenses increased 10.6%. The group's non-fare business, including taxi and rental operations, saw a 6.1% increase in operating profit to $27.3 million. Despite the losses, SMRT's CEO Desmond Kuek expressed confidence in the company's future, citing potential growth from the Sports Hub and international rail business opportunities.

site_title: No end in sight to Thai political crisis
summary: Thailand is set to hold a contentious general election on Sunday amidst a deepening political crisis. Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra has refused to delay the election despite opposition calls and growing threats from anti-government protesters. The election is expected to be marred by disruptions, with tourist arrivals predicted to fall by half and revenue losses estimated at up to $870 million. The outcome is uncertain, with the ruling party unlikely to form a government due to opposition boycotts and protester-prevented candidate registrations. The country's stability remains precarious, with the possibility of further unrest.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: Fragrance Group's Q4 net profit nearly quadrupled to $133.7 million, driven by a jump in other operating income and rising profit margins for hotels and development projects. Kreuz Holdings shareholders voted in favor of a private equity fund's $445.6 million offer to privatize the firm at 80 cents per share. SP Corporation Ltd's full-year net profit rose 13.8% to $2.4 million, despite a 12% drop in revenue. Thai Village Holdings changed its name to Pavillon Holdings Ltd.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Asian markets declined as economic woes intensified, with Japan, Hong Kong, India, and Indonesia leading the drop. European markets also dipped due to a US stock market correction. In Singapore, the Ministry of Manpower reported a 9.7% increase in job vacancies to 61,900 in September 2013. The government plans to introduce an alternative business structure for the legal industry, and three pre-schools have been chosen for the government's Anchor Operator Scheme. Meanwhile, the ringgit slumped to its weakest level since 2010 due to weak demand for emerging-market assets.

site_title: Mall developer MAF to pump 3b dirhams into Dubai
summary: Dubai mall developer Majid Al Futtaim (MAF) plans to invest 3 billion dirhams over the next five years, doubling its business size by 2018. The investment includes expanding its Dubai businesses, renovating hotels, and opening new Carrefour supermarkets. MAF's revenue for 2013 was 23 billion dirhams, with earnings before interest, depreciation, taxes, and amortisation (EBIDTA) growing 12% to 3.3 billion dirhams. The company aims to expand aggressively in the Middle East and North Africa, with plans to invest in Egypt, Saudi Arabia, and Oman.

site_title: Cuba opens PSA-run Mariel megaport
summary: Cuba has officially opened its new Mariel megaport, a 2,400-metre wharf expected to welcome one million containers per year, despite lacking foreign investment and the US economic embargo. The port, built with Brazilian technical and financial help, aims to establish Cuba as a regional shipping hub, particularly for shipments from Asia after the Panama Canal expansion in 2015. Cuban President Raul Castro and Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff attended the inauguration, with hopes that the project will bring investment and economic growth to the island nation.

site_title: India's 1937 law stalls AirAsia's bid to start flights
summary: AirAsia's bid to start flights in India has been delayed due to a 1937 law invoked by the aviation regulator, which requires public feedback on the airline's application. The law, Aircraft Rules 1937, is unusual in this context, and the regulator has given 30 days for public submissions. AirAsia had initially planned to start operations by the end of December and offer free tickets for some seats. The delay may push the start of flights to as late as October, with Malaysia-based AirAsia CEO Tony Fernandes stating that flights are expected to begin in March.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: Blumont Group has released details on its takeover bid for Australian-listed miner Genesis Resources, with a "reasonable expectation" of one of seven concession licenses being replaced with a 30-year exploitation license. Multi-Chem reported an eight-fold increase in Q4 net distributable income to $1.89 million, driven by new contracts. Hwa Hong Corp's Q4 earnings rose 11% to $2.69 million, with full-year revenue increasing 9% to $28.6 million.

site_title: Surface Mount Q3 plunges, remains in negative equity
summary: Surface Mount Technology, an electronics components maker, reported a 99.2% plunge in Q3 net profit to HK$937,000, or 0.51 HK cents per share. The company remains in negative equity of HK$66.2 million and has until June to exit the watch-list to avoid stock suspension and delisting. The outlook for 2014 remains cautious due to risk factors, with improved economic conditions in Europe and concerns in China.

site_title: Pimco to start 19 active ETFs as Gross diversifies firm
summary: Pimco, the world's largest bond manager, plans to launch 19 actively managed exchange-traded funds (ETFs) to diversify its offerings. This move follows the resignation of CEO Mohamed El-Erian and aims to more than triple its active ETF line-up. The new ETFs will include variations of existing mutual funds, such as StocksPlus and IndexPlus products, which aim to beat the equity market with bonds and derivatives. The move is seen as a strategic step to expand Pimco's presence in the rapidly growing ETF market.

site_title: Global Premium Hotels' Q4 earnings up 20.1%
summary: Global Premium Hotels reported a 20.1% increase in net profit to $5.2 million in Q4, despite a 1.4% dip in revenue to $14.96 million. Lower income tax and administrative expenses contributed to the higher earnings. The company also reduced finance costs by 9.4% due to partial loan repayment and lower interest rates. For the full year, net profit climbed 5% to $19.37 million, while revenue inched up 0.8% to $60.6 million. The group expects stable tourist arrivals but a challenging year due to growing hotel supply and economic uncertainties.

site_title: Time for Asian leaders to step in
summary: Asian leaders should intervene in the escalating tensions between Japan and China, particularly over the Senkaku islands. Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's recent military spending and constitutional revisions have heightened militarism, while China's air defense zone has escalated the situation. The US commander, Samuel Locklear, warned of the risk of accidental confrontation. Asian leaders, including those from ASEAN, Australia, New Zealand, and South Asia, should directly address China and Japan to prevent wider conflict, as diplomatic efforts seem unlikely to succeed.

site_title: VietJetAir close to finalising Airbus order
summary: VietJetAir is close to finalizing a $6.1 billion order for 62 Airbus aircraft, including 14 single-aisle A320, 42 A320Neo, and 6 A321 models. The deal is expected to be signed at the Singapore Airshow next month. The low-cost carrier, Vietnam's first private airline, aims to expand its operations and compete in the South-east Asian low-cost segment.

site_title: Hotel to provide smartphones for guests
summary: Hotel chain The Park Hotel Group will equip its 308 rooms at the Grand Park Orchard flagship with personalized smartphones by March 3, offering guests unlimited free calls to 27 countries. The service, dubbed "handy," aims to enhance guest experiences and will be rolled out at two other local properties this year. The hotel has invested nearly $300,000 in introducing the technology, which will also include pre-loaded travel apps.

site_title: Light bookings support long range tanker rates
summary: Clean tanker rates on major export routes were mixed on Monday, with light bookings supporting transatlantic and long-range markets. Rates for medium-range tankers on the TC2 route from Rotterdam to New York were at $12,800 a day, while those on the US Gulf to Europe route were negative at -$434 a day. Long-range tanker rates were also steady, with LR1 tankers reaching $293 a day and LR2 tankers at $2,850 a day, following a brief increase earlier this month.

site_title: Bigger Singapore Airshow this year
summary: The Singapore Airshow is set to be even bigger than the 2012 edition, with over 1,000 companies attending, up from around 900. The biennial show will be held from Feb 11-16 and will feature a packed programme, including conferences and events on aviation leadership, security, and technology. Orders are expected to be lower than the record US$200 billion at the Dubai Airshow, but organizers are cautiously optimistic about deals. The event will also include a flight display of the A350 XWB and the Black Knights aerobatics team.

images.alt_text: Mr Lau: Will be happy to hit 70-80% of the deals chalked up in the previous show.

site_title: Southwest brand to fly outside the continental US in July
summary: Southwest Airlines will begin flights to Aruba, the Bahamas, and Jamaica in July, marking its first international flights under the Southwest brand. The airline will operate non-stop flights from Atlanta, Baltimore, Orlando, and other cities to these destinations. International flying is seen as a growth opportunity for Southwest, with yields 40% higher than domestic flights. The airline plans to expand to Mexico, the Caribbean, and Central and South America next year, with a focus on routes that customers desire and are currently over-fared.

site_title: The independents
summary: Two avant-garde watch companies, Antoine Martin and Breva, have recently been introduced by Yafriro, a luxury timepiece boutique founded by Iwan Hew. Antoine Martin, led by watchmaker Martin Braun, is known for its innovative designs, including the "Slow Runner" watch that beats at 7,200 beats per hour. Breva, founded by Vincent Dupontreue, is a high-end Swiss watch company that produces mechanical wristwatches with unique features, such as the Genie 01, which forecasts the weather. Both brands aim to break watchmaking rules and offer technologically advanced timepieces.

site_title: Brecht classic adapted for Yue opera
summary: A Yue Opera Troupe from China will stage an adaptation of Bertolt Brecht's 1943 classic "The Good Person of Szechwan" on Feb 15 at the Esplanade Theatre. The production, titled "Good Soul of South Yangtze," will blend traditional Yue Opera elements with modern hip-hop and jazz music, and contemporary costumes. Renowned director Guo Xiaonan is helming the production, aiming to update traditional Chinese art form and infuse it with deeper meanings. The adaptation is part of the Huayi Festival 2014.

site_title: Two for-profit pre-schools among three joining govt scheme
summary: The Singapore government has selected five pre-schools, including two for-profit operators, to join the Anchor Operator Scheme, a program aimed at increasing access to quality and affordable early childhood education. The five chosen pre-schools - E-Bridge, Skool4Kidz, MY World, My First Skool, and PAP Community Foundation - will provide around 16,000 additional childcare spots by 2017. The government aims to create 20,000 new childcare places by 2017, and the selected pre-schools will receive funding support and preferential allocation of choice HDB sites to help achieve this goal.

site_title: Cordlife reaches legal settlement with Cryoviva
summary: Cordlife Group has reached a legal settlement with Cryoviva Singapore, paying damages for trademark and copyright infringement. Cryoviva will pay damages and costs, and its websites have been taken down since January 23. The settlement resolves a lawsuit filed by Cordlife, which claimed Cryoviva had "deliberately and wilfully" used its proprietary information and intellectual property without consent. The outcome aims to protect Cordlife's reputation and goodwill, maintaining the trust of its clients.

site_title: Regulatory tweaks for legal industry on the horizon
summary: Singapore plans to introduce an alternative business structure for the legal industry, allowing non-legal professionals to own a part of a law firm, by next year. This change is part of a review committee's recommendations, which have been accepted by the Ministry of Law. The proposed changes, likely to be implemented through legislative amendments to the Legal Profession Act, aim to attract more foreign-qualified lawyers and international interest in the industry.

site_title: New home sales in December fall more than forecast
summary: US new home sales declined 7% in December to 414,000 annualized pace, down from 445,000 in November. This marks the industry's worst month since 2008. Despite a 16.4% jump in demand for all of last year, the housing market has cooled due to bad weather, rising borrowing costs, and property values. Builders remain optimistic, citing long-term interest rates and a growing population.

site_title: Markets drop as EM woes come together
summary: Asian markets declined due to emerging market woes, including currency volatility in Argentina and Turkey, a political crisis in Thailand, and concerns over growth and financial stability in China. However, observers believe the economic growth environment remains positive, with no contagion effect. The US Federal Reserve's decision on bond purchases is expected to impact emerging markets, but investor sentiment in Europe and the US remains positive, with gains of 20-30% last year. Experts predict global growth to be above average levels, with moderate growth and low inflation favoring equities.

site_title: MBFC owners win property tax refund appeal
summary: The owners of Marina Bay Financial Centre (MBFC) Towers 1 and 2 have won a $6.9 million property tax refund appeal with the Court of Appeal ruling that vacancy refunds extend to fitting-out periods. The ruling overturns a High Court decision, allowing the owners to claim refunds for the period between November 2012 and December 2013, including for the fitting-out periods, despite the removal of the property tax refund provision for vacant properties starting January 1, 2014.

site_title: Wine auction helps raise $1m for charities
summary: A three-day wine event, La Paulee de Singapour, held in Singapore from January 24-26, raised $1 million for charities, including St Andrew's Autism Centre and the Autism Association. The event, organized by Dr NK Yong and his wife Melina, featured a gala charity dinner and wine auction, with wines donated by top producers such as Alvaro Palacios and Domaine Drouhin. A rare Unico Reserva 1989 fetched $29,000, and a surprise auction of chefs' services raised $40,000. A final donor contributed $27,000, surpassing the $1 million target.

site_title: 700 Beach changing hands for some $120m
summary: A Singaporean property site, 700 Beach, is being sold for approximately $120 million. The new owners plan to redevelop the 18,400 sq ft site into a 15-storey hotel with about 300 rooms. The proposed hotel will be managed by UK hospitality group Whitbread under the Premier Inn brand. The redevelopment is expected to be led by Master Contract Services and Fine Grain Property Consortium. The sale marks a significant change for the site, which was previously an eight-storey boutique office block.

site_title: Japan's trade deficit rises to new high
summary: Japan logged a record trade deficit of nearly 11.5 trillion yen ($143 billion) in 2013, driven by a sharp drop in the yen's value and soaring import costs, particularly for fuels and consumer goods. Despite a 9.5% rise in exports, the deficit was two-thirds larger than the previous year, highlighting Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's government's challenges in addressing energy costs and promoting nuclear reactor restarts. The government is instead seeking to cut costs by promoting renewable energy and importing cheaper shale gas.

site_title: Casio shows heavy mettle
summary: Casio is set to rewrite its history with the release of the $1,000 MT-G (metal-twisted G-Shock) timepiece, marking the brand's entry into the high-end analogue watch market. The watch undergoes rigorous testing, including stress tests and durability tests, to ensure its advanced technological capabilities and fine craftsmanship. With only 300 units produced daily, the MT-G is a modern update of the classic G-Shock, featuring a steel case and sapphire crystals, and is available exclusively at luxury boutiques in the US, Japan, and Singapore. This move solidifies Casio's intention to become a serious contender in the analogue watch sector, combining its expertise in digital watches with its new analogue efforts.

site_title: Lion Air buys plane engines worth US$1.2b
summary: Indonesia's Lion Air has purchased CFM International engines worth $1.2 billion for 60 new Airbus A320s on order, aiming to boost capacity in South-east Asia. The budget carrier plans to start delivering new aircraft in mid-2014, with a total of six planes due to be delivered this year. Lion Air seeks to capitalize on Indonesia's growing consumer class and compete internationally with AirAsia.

site_title: ASL Marine to buy Miclyn shipyard for US$20m
summary: ASL Marine has announced plans to acquire Miclyn Express Offshore's Batam shipyard in Indonesia for US$20 million, expanding its facilities and capabilities in shipbuilding and shiprepair. The acquisition, conditional on permit approval, will increase ASL's yard facility by over 35% and supplement its revenue stream. ASL's shipbuilding division saw a 54% increase in gross profits to $59 million in FY13, with an outstanding order book of $370 million. Miclyn will focus on its vessel chartering business after the sale.

site_title: Thai ruling party against delaying polls
summary: Thailand's ruling party opposes delaying the February 2 general election, despite opposition protests and violence that prevented hundreds of thousands from voting in advance polls. The Constitutional Court ruled that the election could be postponed due to civil strife, but the ruling party's head, Jarupong Ruangsuwan, opposes a delay. The opposition Democrats, led by former Prime Minister Abhisit Vejjajiva, may consider participating in a delayed vote, while Abhisit expressed doubts about Yingluck Shinawatra's ability to oversee reforms.

site_title: Wing Tai's profit falls 45% in Q2
summary: Wing Tai Holdings reported a 45% drop in second-quarter net profit to $48.4 million, due to a sharp decline in share of profits from associated and joint venture companies. Revenue fell 23% to $247.6 million, while net profit for the half-year declined 55% to $73 million. The company attributes the decline to property cooling measures and the introduction of the total debt servicing ratio in Singapore, and plans to monitor the market and launch new residential projects.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: China Print Power Group issued a profit warning due to expected losses from an impairment on plant and machinery. Ascendas India Trust opened its 'Aviator' building in Bangalore, leased to two tenants. Figtree Holdings secured a $178m contract to design and build a logistics centre in Jurong West. Marco Polo Marine reported a 28% fall in Q1 net profit to $3.3m, despite a 99% increase in revenue.

site_title: Japan leads regional market rout
summary: Japan's benchmark Nikkei 225 Index plummeted over 3% to below 15,000 points as the US Federal Reserve announced plans to taper its bond-buying program by $10 billion from next month. China's manufacturing contracted for the first time in six months, further weakening regional markets. However, analysts remain positive on Japan, citing the country's economic revival and Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's reforms. In contrast, analysts are cautious on China due to risks in the shadow banking sector and concerns over corporate profit margins.

site_title: Correction
summary: A correction was made to an article published on January 24, 2014, regarding JES's bet on Mineriver. Initially, the article stated that JES had parted with $7 million, but it was later revealed that only $2 million out of the first tranche payment had been completed. The error was pointed out by JES and the publication apologized for the mistake.

site_title: Over 300 fall ill aboard Royal Caribbean cruise
summary: Over 300 passengers and crew members fell ill aboard a Royal Caribbean cruise ship, with 281 passengers and 22 crew members experiencing vomiting and diarrhoea. The 10-day Caribbean cruise ended two days early due to the outbreak. The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) said the cause of the sickness was unknown, but an environmental safety officer and epidemiologist will investigate. The ship's crew increased cleaning and disinfection procedures, and Royal Caribbean announced the early return to its home port in New Jersey.

site_title: Scientists: ageing ISS crucial to research
summary: The International Space Station (ISS) has been extended by four years, until at least 2024, allowing for more global research and scientific collaboration. The US$100 billion space station offers enormous scientific and societal benefits, including studying the effects of weightlessness on the human body and testing new space technologies for Mars missions. The ageing structure requires regular maintenance, and private funding is also supporting research at the ISS, with possibilities described as "unlimited". The extended life will allow for critical benefits to be delivered to the nation and the world, maintaining American leadership in space.

site_title: Yoma blends whisky production into Myanmar expansion
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings, a real estate developer, is investing US$3.3 million upfront and up to US$11.1 million to acquire a 30% stake in Asia Beverages Co (ABC), maker of High Class blended whisky in Myanmar. PMM Partners, a joint venture between Yoma chairman Serge Pun and Simon Murray & Co, will also take a 20% stake. The investment marks Yoma's first foray into the fast-moving consumer goods sector, expanding its diversification push beyond real estate.

site_title: Pirates looted ship off Angola, maintain owners
summary: A Greek-owned oil tanker, MT Kerala, was reportedly hijacked by pirates off the Angolan coast on January 18, according to the ship's owners, Dynacom. The crew had managed to contact the owners, stating that pirates had stolen a large quantity of cargo. This contradicts an Angolan navy account that claimed the crew had faked a pirate attack to disable communications. The incident has raised concerns about piracy spreading south from the Gulf of Guinea, near Africa's largest oil producer Nigeria.

site_title: Boeing 787 under probe for overheated battery
summary: A battery on a Boeing 787 Dreamliner overheated on January 14, prompting concerns about its safety. The incident, similar to previous problems, has Japan's Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism Ministry investigating, but operations have not been suspended. Boeing has improved batteries and identified 80 potential causes, with three safeguard measures to prevent overheating and fire. The ministry plans to analyze the battery using a CT scan and will closely monitor the situation due to the minor damage.

site_title: China Credit close to averting default on troubled product
summary: China Credit Trust, a shadow banking product, is close to averting a default, with an agreement reportedly near completion. The $633.3 million trust, set to mature on January 31, would have been the industry's first default. Chinese regulators opposed an alternative proposal to allow the default, citing the large amount of money involved. A successful resolution would test investors' nerves over the health of China's financial system, and a series of shadow banking products due to mature this year may still pose a risk to the country's banking system.

site_title: Bridge Alliance forms region's largest M2M partnership
summary: The Bridge Alliance, a SingTel-linked coalition of telcos, has formed the Asia-Pacific region's largest Machine-to-Machine (M2M) alliance. The alliance, comprising 11 operators, offers M2M services to a combined base of over 500 million subscribers, eliminating the need to deal with multiple operators. The partnership aims to provide significant commercial benefits and economies of scale, challenging the role of intermediaries in the region. This move is seen as a response to the complexities of navigating Asia-Pacific's varied economies, technological development, and regulatory requirements.

site_title: OSIM's Q4 earnings rise 22% to $27.6m
summary: OSIM International reported a 22% year-over-year increase in Q4 net profit to $27.6 million, driven by higher consumer demand for wellness products and a $42.1 million gain from the fair value of TWG Tea. Revenue rose 15.5% to $178.6 million, exceeding the previous high in 2006. The group's profit before taxes reached a record $101.6 million for FY2013, driven by increased sales of new products and a focus on Asia markets, particularly China, where sales grew double-digit.

site_title: Bracing for the onslaught of US shale plants
summary: US shale revolution boosts US oil refining industry, leading to a global refining overcapacity and decline of basic oil refineries worldwide. European refineries face the greatest stress, with environmental concerns further threatening smaller refineries. Singapore's refineries, however, remain a stronghold, thanks to investments from ExxonMobil and Shell. Despite cost advantages, Singapore's industry may struggle to compete with US ethane crackers, prompting the government to increase support and efforts to reduce energy costs.

site_title: LionGold's gold reserves less than thought
summary: LionGold's technical report on its Bolivia mine has revised its gold reserves downward, but a higher gold price estimate boosts free cash to US$269 million, a 96% increase from the original estimate. The company plans to develop the project in two phases to reduce risks, with a capital expenditure of US$167.7 million. Despite lower reserves, LionGold expects to generate significant free cash and improve its net present value and internal rate of return. Production is expected to start next year.

site_title: MAHB's earnings dip 1.3% to RM389m as operating costs jump
summary: MAHB's earnings dropped 1.3% to RM389m in 2013, despite a 9.7% projected passenger growth this year. The airport operator attributes the decline to increased operating costs, including a 28% rise in staff costs and 15% increase in maintenance and retail overheads. The start of the new budget terminal in May is expected to boost future performance, with KLIA2 set to host more passengers. MAHB's revenue rose 15.5% to over RM4 billion, but earnings per share fell to 31.73 sen.

site_title: GLP lands tenants for China properties
summary: MAINBOARD-listed Global Logistic Properties (GLP) has leased 43,000 square meters of space across China to three companies. Sankyu Logistics, LightInTheBox.com, and Watsons have signed agreements for 16,000, 15,000, and 12,000 square meters of space, respectively. The leases are part of GLP's expansion efforts in China's retail and logistics industries, with domestic consumption driving demand. The company operates in China, Japan, and Brazil, with China accounting for 59% of its net asset value.

site_title: Asia's 1st luxe Nobu Hotel to open in Manila complex
summary: Nobu Hotel to open in Manila's US$1.3 billion City of Dreams complex, targeting wealthy Chinese gamblers. The 321-room hotel will feature Michelin-starred Chef Nobu's signature cuisine, aiming to position Manila as an alternative gaming destination to Macau. The complex, a joint venture of Melco Crown Entertainment Ltd and Belle Corp, also includes a casino, nightclub, and theme park, set to open by mid-year. The hotel's opening is seen as a bet on the Philippines and China, with the goal of attracting Chinese gamblers and establishing Manila as a weekend getaway.

site_title: The value of quarterly reporting
